title: Teen ‘killed by ex-boyfriend’ was previously fined for wasting police time
text:
Shana Grice, 19, was issued with a fine for wasting police time after she complained about her ex-boyfriend assaulting her (Picture: PA) A teenager who was found dead with her throat slit months after reporting her ex-boyfriend to police was issued with a fine for wasting police time, a court has heard. 
Shana Grice, 19, was found dead in her bedroom in Portslade, East Sussex, following an attack on August 25 last year.
Abusive ex-boyfriend ‘stalked victim, slit her throat and set her room on fire’ Her ex-boyfriend, Michael Lane, 27, is accused of murdering her after she started seeing her former partner Ashley Cooke again.
A jury heard how Lane became ‘obsessed’ with the teenager and started stalking her in February 2016.
Ms Grice informed police after he allegedly hid outside her house, left unwanted flowers and a note that read ‘Shona will always cheat on you’ on Mr Cooke’s car.
But police treated the incident as ‘low risk’, jurors were told.
Michael Lane, 27, is accused of murdering Ms Grice after she started seeing her former partner Ashley Cooke again. (Picture: PA) A month later, Ms Grice reported that Lane had assaulted her, but he denied the allegation and provided texts that suggested she wanted to be in a relationship with him.
Man accused of slitting ex’s throat checked lottery after finding her body The court heard that Ms Grice was then charged with ‘having caused wasteful employment of police by making a false report’ because she failed to disclose that Lane was her on-off boyfriend, and was issued with a fixed-penalty notice.
In the months leading up to Shana’s death Lane, who was a tyre and exhaust fitter, secretly put a tracking device in her car and turned up unannounced at her home, the court heard.
He also stole Ms Grice’s keys and broke into her home to watch her sleep, which he was cautioned by police for.
Then, on August 25, Lane waited until the last person had left Ms Grice’s home in Brighton before letting himself in.
He then allegedly slashed the victim’s throat, and set fire to her bedroom.

Ms Grice’s body was discovered by her Mr Cooke’s dad, Ian, face-down on the bed in the smoke-filled room, after colleagues reported that she had failed to turn up for work.
Giving evidence in his defence, Lane said his actions were motivated by a desire to know why she had abruptly ended their relationship.
He told the court the pair had sex two nights before her death and claimed he was shocked when he discovered her body after her front door was left open.
Lane, who got to know Miss Grice while they worked at Brighton Fire Alarms, denies murder.
